sen.j: 邪馬台国（やまたいこく）は、『魏志倭人伝』などに出てくる国である。
sen.e: Yamatai (邪馬台国) is a vassal state which is mentioned in Gishiwajinden ('Worenchuan' [the account of the people of 'Wa'] in "Wei chih" [The History of the Wei Dynasty]).
sen.cmt: 邪馬台国の説明については下記を参照しました。http://www.britannica.com/EBchecked/topic/300531/Japan/214442/History?anchor=ref276114「魏志倭人伝」の英訳について、初出のみ Gishiwajinden ('Worenchuan' [the account of the people of 'Wa'] in "Wei shu" [The History of the Wei Dynasty]) としました。2度目からは、書物の題名ではないこと、しかし日本では「魏志倭人伝」としてある意味独立したセクションとして取り上げられ考察の対象とされていることを考慮し、日本語のローマ字表記で Gishiwajinden としました。ただし、Encyclopedia Britanica 等の英語文章では初出のみ魏志倭人伝についての説明が入り、その後からは「魏書」 'Wei chih' が出典先として記載されるのが一般的なようです。参照：http://www.jstor.org/pss/2385316ただし、魏書、及びその他の中国の書物の題名に関しては、まず北京語のローマ字表記で記し、その後（）内で英訳を付記する形をとりました。この後の文で邪馬台国の別の漢字表記について取り上げられているので、違いを明確にするため漢字表記を（）内に付記しました。
sen.e: Yamatai (邪馬台国) is a vassal state which is mentioned in Gishiwajinden ('Worenchuan' [the account of the people of 'Wa'] in "Wei chih" [The History of the Wei Dynasty]).

sen.j: 弥生時代の2世紀～3世紀に日本にあったと推定されている。
sen.e: Yamatai is presumed to be in Japan from the 2nd to the 3rd century, in the Yayoi period.

sen.j: 女王が治めていたことから魏志倭人伝では女王国とも記されている。
sen.e: Because a queen ruled the coutry, it was referred to as a queen's country in Gishiwajinden.

sen.j: 邪馬台国は元々男王が治めていたが、国家成立から70～80年後、倭国全体で長期間にわたる騒乱が起きた（倭国大乱）。
sen.e: Although kings had originally run Yamatai, long-term turmoil occurred throughout Wa (Japan) 70 to 80 years after the establishment of the state (The civil war in Wa).
sen.cmt: 「倭国」は中国語読みの英語表記の 'Wo' ではなく、日本語読みのローマ字表記で 'Wa' とし、「倭国大乱」は The civil war in Wa と訳出しました。参考：http://www.britannica.com/EBchecked/topic/300531/Japan/214442/History?anchor=ref276114
sen.e: Although kings had originally run Yamatai, long-term turmoil occurred throughout Wa (Japan) 70 to 80 years after the establishment of the state (The civil war in Wa).

sen.j: 邪馬台国もその影響を逃れえず、卑弥呼という女子を王に共立することによって、ようやく混乱が収まった。
sen.e: Yamatai was unable to escape from this influence, but the chaos was remedied by putting in place a woman called Himiko as a co-queen sovereign.

sen.j: 弟が彼女を補佐し国を治めていた。
sen.e: Her younger brother assisted her in ruling the state.

sen.j: 女王は魏に使節を派遣し親魏倭王の封号を得た。
sen.e: The queen sent an envoy to Wei and received the title given to a country engaged in a vassel relationship with China: Shingi Wao (the ruler of Wa).
sen.cmt: 親魏倭王の英訳について、女性は 'king' にはなりえないことから、ここでは 'ruler' としました。
sen.e: The queen sent an envoy to Wei and received the title given to a country engaged in a vassal relationship with China: Shingi Wao (the ruler of Wa).

sen.j: 248年頃、狗奴国との戦いの最中に卑弥呼が死去し、男王が後継に立てられたが混乱を抑えることができず、「壹與」（壱与）または「臺與」（台与）が女王になることで収まったという。
sen.e: It is apparent that although a man was appointed king when Himiko died during the war against Kuna (another state in Japan) around 248, he was unable to resolve the turmoil at the time, which was only cleaned up when 'Iyo' (壹與 [壱与]) or 'Toyo' (臺與 [台与}) became a queen sovereign.
sen.cmt: 狗奴国の説明として、(other country in Japan) と英訳では付記しました。
sen.e: It is apparent that although a man was appointed king when Himiko died during the war against Kuna (another state in Japan) around 248, he was unable to resolve the turmoil at the time, which was only cleared up when 'Iyo' (壹與 [壱与]) or 'Toyo' (臺與 [台与}) became a queen sovereign.

sen.j: 邪馬台国と後のヤマト王権の関係ははっきりしない。
sen.e: The relationship between Yamatai and later Yamato kingdom (the ancient Japanese kingdom) is uncertain.

sen.e: Concerning the location too, there is a lot of argument because the accounts in Gishiwajinden are puzzling.

sen.e: It is generally read 'Yamatai' but there are various theories as to how it was read originally.

tit.e: The route and journey towards Yamatai

sen.j: 魏志倭人伝には、魏 (三国)の領土で朝鮮半島北部に当時あった郡から邪馬台国に至る道程が記されている。
sen.e: The route and journey towards Yamatai from a commandery, which existed in the northern part of Korean Peninsula at that time and was a territory of the Wei dynasty (Three Kingdoms Period), is written in Gishiwajinden.

sen.j: 漢書で一般的な里約400メートルを用い、方角も正確だとの前提に立って直線距離で考えると、上陸地点から陸行500里の伊都国は、九州北岸から200km東南の宮崎県＝日向としか読めない。
sen.e: If you use ri, which is about 400 meters and is generally used in historical records of the Han Dynasty, and think in a straight line bearing right, there is only one possible location for the state of Ito which was 500 ri in-land from the embarkation point, that is Hyuga, Miyazaki Province, 200 Km to the southeast of the northern shore of Kyushu.

If you use ri as a measurement of distance, which is about 400 meters and is generally used in historical records of the Han Dynasty, and think in a straight line bearing right, there is only one possible location for the state of Ito which was 500 ri in-land from the embarkation point, that is Hyuga, Miyazaki Province, 200 Km to the southeast of the northern shore of Kyushu.

sen.cmt: Miyazaki Province→Miyazaki Prefectureに訂正しました。

sen.j: （江戸時代以前の国学者は、そう考え、後の耶馬台国までの記事は誤記と考えた。）

sen.j: そこから単純に100里+100里＝200里が不弥国（大隅半島付近？）と考えると、さらに10日南に水行する邪馬台国なるものは日本列島を飛び越えて太平洋上になってしまう。
sen.e: If the journey is simply 200 ri (100 ri plus 100ri) from Ito, ending up in the state of Fumi (possibly near today's Osumi Peninsula), to then travel south by sea for 10 days would mean that Yamatai is located in the Pacific Ocean, past the Japanese islands.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処 The Japanese here is very confusing, and perhaps ought to be checked before it is translated into English.
sen.e: If the journey is simply 200 ri (100 ri plus 100ri) from Ito, one would end up in the state of Fumi (possibly near today's Osumi Peninsula); from there, traveling south by sea for 10 days would mean that Yamatai is located in the Pacific Ocean, past the Japanese islands.

sen.j: 邪馬台国には元々は男王が置かれていたが、国家成立から70～80年を経たころ、漢の霊帝の光和年間に政情不安が起きた。
sen.e: Although men had originally been placed as sovereigns in Yamatai, 70 to 80 years after the establishment of the state, which was during the Guanghe period (178 to 184) of the Emperor Ling in Han, political instability took hold, and after long years of war a woman was placed as co-sovereign.

sen.j: 卑弥呼に関する「魏志倭人伝」のこの記述から、卑弥呼は呪術を司る巫女（シャーマン）のような人物であり、邪馬台国は原始的な呪術国家とする見方がある。
sen.e: Because of the description about Himiko in 'Gishiwajinden,' some say that Himiko was a shaman-like person who conducted magic and that Yamatai was a primitive magic state.

sen.j: 一方で、弟が政治を補佐したという記述から、巫女の卑弥呼が神事を司り、実際の統治は男子が行う二元政治とする見方もある。
sen.e: On the other hand, based on references to her younger brother supporting the government, there is also a view that Yamatai had a binary system of government in which shaman Himiko conducted the ritual and men delivered the real administration.

On the other hand, based on references to her younger brother's support of the government, there is also a view that Yamatai had a binary system of government in which shaman Himiko conducted the rituals and men delivered the real administration.

sen.j: 女王を戴いてたことから邪馬台国を女系国家と論じる者もいるが、卑弥呼以前は男王が立ち、卑弥呼の死後もまず男王が立っていることから、これは疑わしい。
sen.e: Some people say that Yamatai was a matriarchal state because it had queens as sovereigns, but this is problematic since a king ruled before Himiko and another king ruled right after Himiko's death.

The Ito state was the centre of diplomacy, where envoys and translators from Wei and Han stayed and had their written materials and gifts checked to send to the queen.
sen.cmt: 「文書や贈物の点検を受け女王に送っていた。」の部分の訳をより原文に沿うよう訂正しました。

sen.j: 租税や賦役の徴収が行われ、国々にはこれらを収める倉がつくられていた。
sen.e: The land tax and Fueki (tax paid in the form of labour) were collected, and each state built storehouses to store the land tax.
The land tax and Fueki (tax paid in the form of labour) were collected, and each state built storehouses to store the land tax.
The land tax and Fueki (tax paid in the form of labour) were collected, and each state built storehouses to store the land tax.

sen.j: また、市場が各地に開かれ、大倭という官がこれを監督していた。
sen.e: Also, markets were opened in various places, monitored by officers called Tai.
Also, markets were opened in various places, monitored by officers called Tai.
Also, markets were opened in various places, monitored by officers called Tai.

sen.j: 女王は景初2年（239年）以降、帯方郡を通じ数度にわたって魏に使者を送り、皇帝から親魏倭王に任じられた。
sen.e: Queen Himiko sent envoys to Wei through Daifang Commandery a couple of times after 239, and she was appointed as the ruler of Wa by the Emperor.
sen.cmt: 「帯方」の英訳参照： http://ejje.weblio.jp/content/Daifang+Commandery 親魏倭王の英訳について、女性は 'king' にはなりえないことから、ここでは 'ruler' としました。
sen.e: Queen Himiko sent envoys to Wei through Daifang Commandery a couple of times after 239, and she was appointed as the ruler of Wa by the Emperor.
Queen Himiko sent envoys to Wei through Daifang Commandery a couple of times after 239, and she was appointed as the ruler of Wa by the Emperor.

sen.j: 正始 (魏)8年（248年）には、狗奴国との紛争に際し、帯方郡から塞曹掾史張政が派遣されている。
sen.e: An official called Zhang Zheng (Chang Cheng) was dispatched from Daifang Commandery for a dispute against the state of Kuna in 248.
sen.cmt: 「塞曹掾史張政」は 'An official called Zhang Zheng (Chang Cheng) ' と訳しました。参照：http://www.imperialchina.org/Japanese.shtml
sen.e: An official called Zhang Zheng (Chang Cheng) was dispatched from Daifang Commandery because of a dispute with the state of Kuna in 248.
An official called Zhang Zheng (Chang Cheng) was dispatched from Daifang Commandery because of a dispute with the state of Kuna in 248.

sen.j: 魏志倭人伝の記述によれば、朝鮮半島の国々とも使者を交換していたらしい。
sen.e: According to the description in Gishiwajinden, Yamatai apparently exchanged envoys with countries on the Korean Peninsula.
According to the description in Gishiwajinden, Yamatai apparently exchanged envoys with countries on the Korean Peninsula.
According to the description in Gishiwajinden, Yamatai apparently exchanged envoys with countries on the Korean Peninsula.

sen.j: 卑弥呼が死去すると大きな墳墓がつくられ、100人が殉葬された。
sen.e: When Himiko died, a huge tomb was constructed and 100 people followed her to the grave.
When Himiko died, a huge tomb was constructed and 100 people followed her to the grave.
When Himiko died, a huge tomb was constructed and 100 people followed her to the grave.

sen.j: その後、男王が立てられたが、人々はこれに服さず内乱となり1,000人が死んだ。
sen.e: After her death, although a man became king, people didn't obey him and a domestic conflict ensued which led to the deaths of 1,000 people.
After her death, although a man became king, people didn't obey him and a domestic conflict ensued which led to the deaths of 1,000 people.
After her death, although a man became king, people didn't obey him and a domestic conflict ensued which led to the deaths of 1,000 people.

sen.j: そのため、卑弥呼の親族で13歳の少女だった壹与（台与）が王に立てられた。
sen.e: As a result, Iyo (壹与 [台与]), a 13 old girl who was a relative of Himiko, was appointed as queen.
As a result, Iyo (壹与 [台与]), a 13 old girl who was a relative of Himiko, was appointed as queen.
As a result, Iyo (壹与 [台与]), a 13-year-old girl who was a relative of Himiko, was appointed as queen.
sen.cmt: 13 old girl→13-year-old girlに訂正しました。

sen.j: 先に倭国に派遣された張政は檄文をもって壱与を諭しており、壹与もまた魏に使者を送っている。
sen.e: Zhang Zheng (Chang Cheng), who had been dispatched to Wa before, encouraged Iyo to follow what he advised; Iyo sent envoys to Wei too.
Zhang Zheng (Chang Cheng), who had been dispatched to Wa before, encouraged Iyo to follow what he advised; Iyo sent envoys to Wei too.
Zhang Zheng (Chang Cheng), who had been dispatched to Wa before, encouraged Iyo to follow what he advised; Iyo sent envoys to Wei too.

tit.e: Diplomacy with Wei and Chin Dynasty
Diplomacy with Wei and Chin Dynasty
Diplomacy with Wei and Chin Dynasty

sen.j: 「魏志倭人伝」には、帯方郡を通じた邪馬台国と魏との交渉が記録されている。
sen.e: There is a record of the diplomatic relations between Yamatai and Wei through Daifang Commandery in 'Gishiwajinden.'
There is a record of the diplomatic relations between Yamatai and Wei through Daifang Commandery in 'Gishiwajinden.'
There is a record of the diplomatic relations between Yamatai and Wei through Daifang Commandery in 'Gishiwajinden.'

sen.j: 景初2年（238年）または同3年（239年）の6月、女王は大夫の難升米と次使の都市牛利を帯方郡に派遣し、天子に拝謁を願い出た。
sen.e: In June 238 or 239, Queen Himiko sent Commissioner Nashime and deputy Tsushi Gori to Daifang Commandery in order to ask for an audience with the Emperor.
sen.cmt: 「都市牛利」の読みは下記を参照しました。http://kotobank.jp/word/%E9%83%BD%E5%B8%82%E7%89%9B%E5%88%A9
sen.e: In June 238 or 239, Queen Himiko sent Commissioner Nashime and deputy Tsushi Gori to Daifang Commandery in order to ask for an audience with the Emperor.
In June 238 or 239, Queen Himiko sent Commissioner Nashime and deputy Tsushi Gori to Daifang Commandery in order to ask for an audience with the Emperor.

sen.j: 帯方太守の劉夏は彼らを都に送り、使者は男の生口（奴隷）4人と女の生口6人、班布2匹2丈を献じた。
sen.e: Governor-General Liu Xia of Daifang Commandary in Korea sent them to the capital of Wei, and the envoy made the Emperor presents of 4 male slaves, 6 female slaves and a textile product which was 53 centimeters in width, 24.2 meters in length.
sen.cmt: 「帯方太守の劉夏」の英訳は下記参照しました：http://www.imperialchina.org/Japanese.shtml「班布2匹2丈」については下記参照の上英訳しました：http://plus.yomiuri.co.jp/article/words/%E7%8F%AD%E5%B8%83
sen.e: Governor-General Liu Xia of Daifang Commandary in Korea sent them to the capital of Wei, and the envoy gave the Emperor presents of 4 male slaves, 6 female slaves and a textile product which was 53 centimeters in width, 24.2 meters in length.

Governor-General Liu Xia of Daifang Commandery in Korea sent them to the capital of Wei, and the envoy gave the Emperor presents of 4 male slaves, 6 female slaves and a textile product which was 53 centimeters in width, 24.2 meters in length.
sen.cmt: Commandary→スペルミスのためCommanderyに訂正しました。

sen.j: 悦んだ魏の皇帝（景初2年だとすると曹叡、景初3年だとすると曹芳）は女王を親魏倭王とし、金印紫綬を授けるとともに銅鏡100枚を含む莫大な下賜品を与えた。
sen.e: Emperor of Wei (Cao Rui [Emperor Ming] if it was in 238 and Cao Fang in 239), who was pleased with this, conferred the title of the ruler of Wa (Japan) upon Queen Himiko and endowed her a gold seal with a purple ribbon, as well as enormous gifts including 100 bronze mirrors.
sen.cmt: 親魏倭王の英訳について、女性は 'king' にはなりえないことから、ここでは 'ruler' としました。
sen.e: The Emperor of Wei (Cao Rui [Emperor Ming] if it was in 238 and Cao Fang in 239), who was pleased with this, conferred the title of the ruler of Wa (Japan) upon Queen Himiko. He also endowed her a gold seal with a purple ribbon, as well as enormous gifts including 100 bronze mirrors.

The Emperor of Wei (Cao Rui [Emperor Ming] if it was in 238 and Cao Fang in 239), who was pleased with this, conferred the title of the ruler of Wa (Japan) upon Queen Himiko and endowed her the Gold Seal with Purple Ribbon, as well as enormous gifts including 100 bronze mirrors.
sen.cmt: ネイティブチェッカーに訂正された文はピリオドで二つに分かれていますが、一文になるよう訂正しました。a gold seal with a purple ribbon→the Gold Seal with Purple Ribbonに訂正しました。

sen.j: また、難升米を率善中郎将、牛利を率善校尉とした。
sen.e: Also, the Emperor appointed Nashime as Lieutenant Colonel in the Imperial Guard and Gori as Commandant in the Imperial Guard.
sen.cmt: 「率善中郎将」および「率善校尉」の英訳については下記参照しました。http://books.google.com/books?id=7pEOicqsjv0C&pg=PA301&lpg=PA301&dq=Wei+Nashime&source=bl&ots=vutQpuleZ7&sig=cnkM0OK8vY0HOB83_i2FeYeKlD4&hl=ja&ei=qjxZTODzN5f60wTbnt3oCA&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=2&ved=0CB0Q6AEwAQ#v=onepage&q=Wei%20Nashime&f=false
sen.e: Also, the Emperor appointed Nashime as Lieutenant Colonel in the Imperial Guard and Gori as Commandant in the Imperial Guard.
Also, the Emperor appointed Nashime as Lieutenant Colonel in the Imperial Guard and Gori as Commandant in the Imperial Guard.

sen.j: 8月23日帯方郡と楽浪郡を支配していた公孫淵が司馬懿により斬首される。
sen.e: On 23rd August, Gongsun Yuan, who had controlled Daifang and Lelang Commandery (an ancient county in the northern Korean Peninsula), was beheaded by Sima Yi.
sen.cmt: 「楽浪郡」の英訳については下記を参照しました。http://opac.ndl.go.jp/articleid/9560245/jpn
sen.e: On 23rd August, Gongsun Yuan, who had controlled Daifang and Lelang Commandery (an ancient county in the northern Korean Peninsula), was beheaded by Sima Yi.
On 23rd August, Gongsun Yuan, who had controlled Daifang and Lelang Commandery (an ancient county in the northern Korean Peninsula), was beheaded by Sima Yi.

sen.j: 帯方郡と楽浪郡が魏に占領される。
sen.e: Daifang and Lelang Commandery were taken over by Wei.
Daifang and Lelang Commandery were taken over by Wei.
Daifang and Lelang Commandery were taken over by Wei.

sen.j: 正始 (魏)元年（240年）、帯方太守弓遵は建中校尉梯儁らに詔書と印綬を持たせて倭国へ派遣し、倭王の位を仮授するとともに下賜品を与えた。
sen.e: In 240, Governor-General Gong Zun of Daifang Commandary dispatched Ti Zhun, a commandant of the Imperial Guard, with imperial rescript and ribbon seal to Wa, conferring upon Himiko the title of the ruler of Wa (Japan), together with gifts.
sen.cmt: 「建中校尉梯儁」の英訳は下記を参照しました。http://kongming.net/encyclopedia/Queen-Himiko親魏倭王の英訳について、女性は 'king' にはなりえないことから、ここでは 'ruler' としました。
sen.e: In 240, Governor-General Gong Zun of Daifang Commandary dispatched Ti Zhun, a commandant of the Imperial Guard, with the imperial rescript and ribbon seal to Wa, conferring upon Himiko the title of the ruler of Wa (Japan), along with other gifts.

In 240, Governor-General Gong Zun of Daifang Commandery dispatched Ti Zhun, a commandant of the Imperial Guard, with the imperial rescript and ribbon seal to Wa, conferring upon Himiko the title of the ruler of Wa (Japan), along with other gifts.
sen.cmt: Commandary→スペルミスのためCommanderyに訂正しました。

sen.j: 正始4年（244年）、女王は再び魏に使者として大夫伊聲耆、掖邪狗らを送り、生口と布を献上。
sen.e: In 244, the queen sent envoys, such as Commissioner Iseeki and Ekiyaku, to Wei again and gave the Emperor slaves and textile product as presents.
sen.cmt: 「伊聲耆」および「掖邪狗」の読み方について下記を参照しました。http://kotobank.jp/word/%E6%8E%96%E9%82%AA%E7%8B%97
sen.e: In 244, the queen sent envoys, such as Commissioner Iseeki and Ekiyaku, to Wei again and gave the Emperor slaves and textile product as presents.
In 244, the queen sent envoys, such as Commissioner Iseri and Ekiyaku, to Wei again and gave the Emperor slaves and textile product as presents.

sen.j: 皇帝（曹芳）は掖邪狗らを率善中郎将とした。
sen.e: Emperor (Cao Fang) appointed envoys including Ekiyaku as Lieutenant Colonel in the Imperial Guard.
Emperor (Cao Fang) appointed envoys including Ekiyaku as Lieutenant Colonel in the Imperial Guard.
Emperor (Cao Fang) appointed envoys including Ekiyaku as Lieutenant Colonel in the Imperial Guard.

sen.j: 正始6年（246年）、皇帝（斉王）は帯方郡を通じ難升米に黄幢（黄色い旗さし）を下賜した。
sen.e: In 246, Emperor (King of Qi) gave Nashime a yellow streamer via Daifang Commandery.
In 246, Emperor (King of Qi) gave Nashime a yellow streamer via Daifang Commandery.
In 246, Emperor (King of Qi) gave Nashime a yellow streamer via Daifang Commandery.

sen.j: 正始8年（248年）、女王は太守王頎に載斯烏越を使者として派遣して、狗奴国との戦いについて報告。
sen.e: In 248, Queen Himiko sent an envoy, Sashiuetsu, to Governor-General Wang Qi to inform him of the war against the state of Kuna.
In 248, Queen Himiko sent an envoy, Sashiuetsu, to Governor-General Wang Qi to inform him of the war against the state of Kuna.
In 248, Queen Himiko sent an envoy, Sashiuetsu, to Governor-General Wang Qi to inform him of the war against the state of Kuna.

sen.j: 太守は塞曹掾史張政らを倭国に派遣した。
sen.e: The Governor-General sent officials, such as Zhang Zheng (Chang Cheng), to Wa.
sen.cmt: 「塞曹掾史張政」は'An official called Zhang Zheng (Chang Cheng) 'と訳しました。参照：http://www.imperialchina.org/Japanese.shtml
sen.e: The Governor-General sent officials, such as Zhang Zheng (Chang Cheng), to Wa.
The Governor-General sent officials, such as Zhang Zheng (Chang Cheng), to Wa.

sen.j: 女王に就いた壹与は、帰任する張政に掖邪狗ら20人を同行させた。
sen.e: Iyo, who took over the throne, made Zhang Zheng who was going back to his country, bring 20 people including Ekiyaku, together; they went to the capital of Wei and gave the Emperor 30 slaves (male and female), 5,000 pearls, 2 jades and figured fabric with exotic patterns which was 53 centimeters in width, and 184 meters in length.

Iyo, who took over the throne, made Zhang Zheng who was going back to his country, bring 20 people including Ekiyaku, along with him. They went to the capital of Wei and gave the Emperor 30 slaves (male and female), 5,000 pearls, 2 jades and a figured fabric with exotic patterns which was 53 centimeters in width, and 184 meters in length.
Iyo, who took over the throne, made Zhang Zheng who was going back to his country, bring 20 people including Ekiyaku, along with him.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処（ネイティブチェッカーに訂正された文はピリオドで二つに分かれているため、原文も二つに分けました。）

sen.j: 掖邪狗らはそのまま都に向かい男女の生口30人と白珠5,000孔、青大句珠2枚、異文の雑錦20匹を貢いだ。
sen.e: They went to the capital of Wei and gave the Emperor 30 slaves (male and female), 5,000 pearls, 2 jades and a figured fabric with exotic patterns which was 53 centimeters in width, and 184 meters in length.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処（ネイティブチェッカーに訂正された文はピリオドで二つに分かれているため、原文も二つに分けました。）ネイティブチェッカーが指摘している「figured fabric」については英辞郎on the WEBに「紋織物」の訳として載っているのでOKと判断しました。

sen.j: また、『日本書紀』の「神功紀」に引用される『晋書』起居註に、泰始2年（266年）に倭の女王の使者が朝貢したとの記述がある。
sen.e: There is also a description in one of the documents that recorded the Emperor's life, sayings and doings, in "Jin Shu" (History of the Jin Dynasty), which was cited in the Jingu section of "Nihonshoki" (Chronicles of Japan), of envoys from the queen of Wa bringing a tribute to the Chinese court in 266.
sen.cmt: 日本書紀は英語の定訳があるので、初出のみ日本語表記および（）内に英訳を付記し、2度目からは英語定訳のみを用いました。
sen.e: There is also a description in one of the documents that recorded the Emperor's life, sayings and doings, in "Jin Shu" (History of the Jin Dynasty), which was cited in the Jingu section of "Nihonshoki" (Chronicles of Japan), of envoys from the queen of Wa bringing a tribute to the Chinese court in 266.

There is also a description in one of the documents that recorded the Emperor's life, sayings and doings, in "Jin Shu" (History of the Jin Dynasty), which was cited in the Jingu section of "Nihonshoki" (Chronicles of Japan), of envoys from the queen of Wa bringing a tribute to the Chinese court in 266.

sen.j: 魏志の魏書三少帝紀によれば、同じ年に東夷が朝貢して禅譲革命の準備がなされたという記事があるので、この女王は壹与で、魏に代って成立した西晋の皇帝（司馬炎）に朝貢したと考えられている。
sen.e: Because there is an account that the Eastern barbarians brought a tribute to the Chinese court in the same year and made preparations for Zenjo (one of the forms of the emperor replacement whereby the emperor was not decided by succession but instead the throne moved to the most virtuous person) according to 三少帝紀 in Wei chih, this queen must have been Iyo and her envoys apparently brought a tribute to the emperor of the Western Jin Dynasty (Sima Yan) which was established after Wei.
sen.cmt: 三少帝紀の定訳不明です。「禅譲革命」について、下記を参照して Zenjo と英訳し、読者の理解を助けるため、説明を（）内に付記しました。http://kotobank.jp/word/%E7%A6%85%E8%AD%B2
sen.e: Because there is an account that the Eastern barbarians brought a tribute to the Chinese court in the same year and made preparations for Zenjo (one of the forms of the emperor replacement whereby the emperor was not decided by succession but instead the throne moved to the most virtuous person) according to 三少帝紀 in Wei chih, this queen must have been Iyo. Her envoys apparently brought a tribute to the emperor of the Western Jin Dynasty (Sima Yan) which was established after Wei.

Because there is an account that the Eastern barbarians brought a tribute to the Chinese court in the same year and made preparations for Zenjo (one of the forms of the emperor replacement whereby the emperor was not decided by succession but instead the throne moved to the most virtuous person) according to 三少帝紀 in Wei chih, this queen must have been Iyo and her envoys apparently brought a tribute to the emperor of the Western Jin Dynasty (Sima Yan) which was established after Wei.
sen.cmt: 三少帝紀の定訳は確認取れませんでした。ネイティブチェッカーに訂正された文はピリオドで二つに分かれていますが、原文を二つに分けるより翻訳者の元の訳文のように一文で訳したほうが良いと思います。

sen.j: 魏志倭人伝に当時の倭人の風俗も記述されている。
sen.e: In Gishiwajinden, ancient Japanese people's folkways at that time are depicted.
In Gishiwajinden, ancient Japanese people's folkways at that time are depicted.
In Gishiwajinden, ancient Japanese people's folkways at that time are depicted.

sen.j: 男子はみな顔や体に入れ墨を施している。
sen.e: All men were tattooed on their face and body.
All men were tattooed on their face and body.
All men were tattooed on their face and body.

sen.j: 人々は朱や丹を体に塗っている。
sen.e: People painted vermilion and red color onto their bodies.
People painted vermilion and red color onto their bodies.
People painted vermilion and red color onto their bodies.

sen.j: 男子は冠をつけず、髪を結って髷をつくっている。
sen.e: Males didn't wear headgear, and their hair was tied in a topknot.
Males didn't wear headgear, and their hair was tied in a topknot.
Males didn't wear headgear, and their hair was tied in a topknot.

sen.j: 女子はざんばら髪。
sen.e: Females had loose and disheveled hair.
Females had loose and disheveled hair.
Females had loose and disheveled hair.

sen.j: 着物は幅広い布を結び合わせているだけである。
sen.e: They wore large pieces of cloth, with simple knots.
They wore large pieces of cloth, with simple knots.
They wore large pieces of cloth, with simple knots.

sen.j: 兵器は矛、盾、木弓 (武器)を用いる。
sen.e: Pikes, shields and wooden bows (weapon) were used as arms.
Pikes, shields and wooden bows (weapon) were used as arms.
Pikes, shields and wooden bows (weapon) were used as arms.

sen.j: 土地は温暖で、冬夏も生野菜を食べている。
sen.e: As the climate was mild, people ate fresh vegetables both in summer and winter.
As the climate was mild, people ate fresh vegetables both in summer and winter.
As the climate was mild, people ate fresh vegetables both in summer and winter.

sen.j: 人が死ぬと10日あまり哭泣して、もがり（喪）につき肉を食さない。
sen.e: When someone died, people cried loudly, mourned the passing and didn't eat meat for about 10 days.
When someone died, people cried loudly, mourned the passing and didn't eat meat for about 10 days.
When someone died, people cried loudly, mourned the passing and didn't eat meat for about 10 days.

sen.j: 他の人々は飲酒して歌舞する。
sen.e: Others drank alcohol, sang and danced.
Others drank alcohol, sang and danced.
Others drank alcohol, sang and danced.

sen.j: 埋葬が終わると水に入って体を清める。
sen.e: When an entombment was finished, people went into the water to clean their bodies.
When an entombment was finished, people went into the water to clean their bodies.
When an entombment was finished, people went into the water to clean their bodies.

sen.j: 倭の者が船で海を渡る際、持衰が選ばれる。
sen.e: When Wa people sailed the sea using ships, a 'Jisai' would be chosen.
sen.cmt: 「持衰」が人名ではなく役職名であることを明確に表すため、英訳ではクォーテーションマークでくくりました。
sen.e: When Wa people sailed the sea using ships, a 'Jisai' would be chosen.
When Wa people sailed the sea using ships, a 'Jisai' would be chosen.

sen.j: 持衰は人と接さず、虱を取らず、服は汚れ放題、肉は食べずに船の帰りを待つ。
sen.e: The Jisai waited for the ship to return without seeing anybody in the meantime, without catching lice, letting their clothes get dirty and without eating any meat.
The Jisai waited for the ship to return without seeing anybody in the meantime, catching lice, letting their clothes get dirty and without eating any meat.
The Jisai waited for the ship to return without seeing anybody in the meantime, catching lice, letting their clothes get dirty and without eating any meat.

sen.j: 船が無事に帰ってくれば褒美が与えられる。
sen.e: If the ship came back safely, the Jisai would be entitled to rewards.
If the ship came back safely, the Jisai would be entitled to rewards.
If the ship came back safely, the Jisai would be entitled to rewards.

sen.j: 船に災難があれば殺される。
sen.e: But if there was some misfortune, the Jisai would be killed.
But if there was some misfortune, the Jisai would be killed.
But if there was some misfortune, the Jisai would be killed.

sen.j: 特別なことをする時は骨を焼き、割れ目を見て吉凶を占う。
sen.e: When someone had something special coming up, they set fire to a bone to see which way it would crack, as a form of divination.
When someone had something special coming up, they set fire to a bone to see which way it would crack, as a form of divination.
When someone had something special coming up, they set fire to a bone to see which way it would crack, as a form of divination.

sen.j: 長命で、百歳や九十、八十歳の者もいる。
sen.e: People lived for a long time: there were people who were 80, 90 and 100 years old.
People lived for a long time: there were people who were 80, 90 and 100 years old.
People lived for a long time: there were people who were 80, 90 and 100 years old.

sen.j: 女は慎み深く嫉妬しない。

sen.j: 法を犯した場合、軽い者は妻子を没収し、重い者は一族を根絶やしにする。
sen.e: When a law was broken, a person whose crime was relatively minor would have his wife and children confiscated, while someone committed a serious crime would have his whole lineage eradicated.

sen.e: After Iyo's bringing tributes to the court in the middle of the 3rd century, there is no record concerning the Wa state in Chinese history books for nearly 150 years, until the bringing of tributes in 413 by the Wa king San (The five kings of Wa).

tit.j: 邪馬台国に関する論争

sen.j: 邪馬台国があったとされる根拠は、「魏志倭人伝」に残されている（参照→魏志倭人伝）ほか、これ以外の中国の史書にも記載がある。
sen.e: The account of a Yamatai state features in 'Gishiwajinden' and there are also descriptions of it in other Chinese history books.

sen.e: However, not only do the notation systems of Chinese characters depend on the materials available, but also there is no unified understanding as to whether 'Yamataikoku (the state of Yamatai in Japanese)' is the right way to read according to Chinese-style reading of characters in the time when the books were written.

sen.j: また、日本国の正史である『古事記』や『日本書紀』に、邪馬台国や卑弥呼の実像を明確にするには記述が不十分であることなどから、その場所や大和朝廷との関係について長期的な論争が続いている。
sen.e: Also, because there are not enough descriptions in the official history books of Japan, "Kojiki" (The Records of Ancient Matters) and "Chronicles of Japan", in order to discern the reality of Yamatai and Himiko, long-term discussions about the location and the relationship with the Yamato Dynasty continue.

sen.j: この論争が始まったのは、江戸時代後期、新井白石が「古史通或問」において大和国説を説き、「外国之事調書」では筑後国山門郡説を説いた。
sen.e: These controversies began in the late Edo period, when Hakuseki ARAI discussed the Yamato Province theory in 'Koshitsuwakumon' and offered the Yamato County in Chikugo Province theory in 'Gaikokunokoto shirabegaki.'

sen.j: その後、国学者の本居宣長は「日本の皇室が中国に朝貢するなどありえない」という立場から、「馭戎概言」において大和国とは別の筑紫（九州）にあった小国であり、卑弥呼は神功皇后の名を騙った熊襲の女酋長であると説いた。
sen.e: After that, a scholar of Japanese classical literature Norinaga MOTOORI, claimed that 'it is unlikely that the Japanese Imperial family took tribute to China': in 'Gyoju Gaiden' he claimed that Yamatai was a small state in Chikushi (Kyushu), distinct from Yamato Province, and that Himiko was a female chief of Kumaso (a tribe living in the ancient Kyushu district) who assumed the false name of Empress Jingu.

sen.e: There are theories about the indefinite nature of the notation: a theory that '壹' is a writing error of '臺,' an alternative theory that they were written distinctly to avoid confusion, which can be guessd from '壹與遣,倭大夫率善中郎將掖邪狗等二十人送,政等還。因詣臺,' and another theory that the letter '臺,' which indicated the place in which the emperors of Wei lived, was not supposed to be used for the country name of the eastern barbarians.

sen.j: もともとは学者間の論争であったが、1967年に発表された宮崎康平の『まぼろしの邪馬台国』（講談社）という書籍によって邪馬台国論争は「邪馬台国ブーム」となり、日本人一般にまで波及した。
sen.e: Although the controversies were originally among scholars, the Yamatai controversy became a 'Yamataikoku boom,' triggered by a book called "Yamatai: the Phantom Kingdom" (Kodansha), by Kohei MIYAZAKI, published in 1967: the controversies now spread to the general Japanese population.

sen.j: 邪馬台国の所在地については日本国内どころか世界各地までにもその地を求める論者がいるが、学界の主流は「畿内説」と「九州説」の二説に大きく分かれている。
sen.e: About the location of Yamatai, although there are some who seek the location worldwide instead of in Japan, academics are mainly divided between two theories: 'the Kinai region theory' and 'the Kyushu theory.'

sen.j: 九州説には、邪馬台国が移動したとする「東遷説」と九州王朝説がある。
sen.e: In the Kyushu theory, there is the 'Tosen theory' (literary, the theory of the capital relocation toward the east), according to which Yamatai was relocated, and the Kyushu dynasty theory.

sen.j: かつて、畿内説は「魏志倭人伝」の方角表記が誤っていると考える研究者（「連続説」、主に京都大学系）に多く見られた。
sen.e: The Kinai region theory is found among many researchers who think the direction written in 'Gishiwajinden' was incorrect ('the contiguous journey theory,' mainly found in connection with Kyoto University), and the Kyushu theory is found among researchers who doubt the description of distance ('the writing error theory,' mainly held in connection with the University of Tokyo; see Kurakichi SHIRATORI and Konan NAITO for details) or researchers who took 'the radial journey theory' as represented by Kazuo ENOKI.

sen.j: 畿内説で用いられる「連続説」（連続読み）とは、魏志倭人伝に記述されている方角や距離に従って比定していく読み方で、帯方郡を出発後、狗邪韓国・対馬国・一支国を経て北部九州に上陸し、末廬国・伊都国・奴国・不弥国・投馬国・邪馬台国までを順にたどる。
sen.e: The 'contiguous journey theory' (reading the journey contiguously), which is used in the Kinai region theory, uses the directions and distances described in Gishiwajinden: after setting out from Daifang Commandery, passing through the state of Kuyakan, Tsuma, Iki to northern Kyushu, and taking the land route through the state of Matsura, Ito, Na, Fumi and Toma to Yamatai.

The 'contiguous journey theory' (reading the journey contiguously), which is used in the Kinai region theory, uses the directions and distances described in Gishiwajinden: after setting out from Daifang Commandery, passing through the state of Kuyakan, Tsuma, Iki to northern Kyushu, and taking the land route through the state of Matsura, Ito, Na, Fumi and Toma to Yamatai.

The 'contiguous journey theory' (reading the journey contiguously), which is used in the Kinai region theory, uses the directions and distances described in Gishiwajinden: after setting out from Daifang Commandery, passing through the state of Kuyakan, Tsuma, Iki to northern Kyushu, and taking the land route through the state of Matsura, Ito, Na, Fumi and Toma to Yamatai.

sen.j: 一方、九州説で用いられる「放射説」（放射読み）は、伊都国までは連続読みと同じだが、その先は伊都国から奴国、伊都国から不弥国、伊都国から投馬国、伊都国から邪馬台国というふうに、伊都国を起点にする読み方である。
sen.e: On the other hand, although 'the radial journey theory' (reading the journey radially), which is used in the Kyushu theory, takes the same route as the contiguous reading until the state of Ito, after that it takes Ito as the starting point, such as Ito to Na, Ito to Fumi, Ito to Toma, and Ito to Yamatai.

On the other hand, although 'the radial journey theory' (reading the journey radially), which is used in the Kyushu theory, takes the same route as the contiguous reading until the state of Ito, after that it takes Ito as the starting point, such as Ito to Na, Ito to Fumi, Ito to Toma, and Ito to Yamatai.

sen.j: なお、宮崎康平は、道程に関して「古代の海岸線は現代とは異なることを想起しなければならない」と指摘し、現在の海岸線で議論を行っていた当時の学会に一石を投じた。
sen.e: In addition, Kohei MIYAZAKI caused a stir in the academic world at that time, where there were discussions concerning the coastline of the time, by pointing out the route and journey and saying 'it should be recalled that the ancient coastline was different from the one at present.'

sen.j: しかし、古代の海岸線を元に考察しても、有利となる場所の相互間のみで変化があるだけで連続説あるいは放射説の根本部分に大きな影響を与えるほどの学説ではないことから現在ではこの点に関しては問題とはされていない。
sen.e: However, even if you look at the possible locations on the basis of the ancient coastline, it is no longer a very influential part of the contiguous journey theory or the radial journey theory because it is not treated as an issue to be discussed anymore, as it would imply only minor alterations to distances where likely locations are concerned (Kinai region and Kyushu).

sen.j: また、近年の考古学的成果、特に年輪年代学による新しい年代観により、大和地方での初期国家の成立が邪馬台国と同時代の2世紀頃までさかのぼるとの説が有力になっている。
sen.e: Because of the archaeological achievements of recent years, especially the new date estimations of dendrochronology, the theory which suggests the establishment of an embryonic nation in Yamato Region going back to about the 2nd century, contemporary with Yamatai, has come to be dominant.

sen.e: As a result, the focus of the controversy is now whether pre-Yamato kingdom (the ancient Japan sovereignty) is connected directly with Yamatai (or whether the embryonic Yamato kingdom is actually the same as Yamatai).

sen.j: 年輪年代学の成果により、画文帯神獣鏡などの記年鏡の年代も一致したことから、邪馬台国の時代にすでに遺跡の築造が始まっていたとみられ、最盛期が弥生時代終末期～古墳時代であり、邪馬台国の時代と合致すること。
sen.e: As the dendrochronological data suggests, because the dates inscribed in mirrors, such as the Gamontai Shinju-kyo Mirror (Mirror with figures of deities and sacred animals), which was excavated from Makimuku ruins, correspond with the time of Yamatai, it is apparent that the construction of the original buildings had already begun in the time of Yamatai and they were in their prime from the late Yayoi period to Tumulus period, which matches the date of Yamatai.

sen.e: It can be seen from earthenware from all over northern Kyushu to southern Kanto excavated from the Makimuku ruins that these buildings played roles such as an exchange center controlling most of the Japanese Islands at that time.

sen.j: 卑弥呼の遣使にちなんだと見られる景初三年、正始元年銘の三角縁神獣鏡が畿内を中心に分布、かつこれらが発掘される古墳の多くは年輪年代学等の結果により3世紀に築造されたと見られ、時代が合致すること。
sen.e: Triangular-rimmed mirrors inscribed 景初三年or 正始元年 (Chinese names of an era, 239), which apparently commemorated Himiko's dispatching of envoys, were distributed centering upon Kinai region, and also many tumulus presumed to have been constructed in the 3rd century - according to the findings of dendrochronology - which matches with the dates of Yamatai.

sen.j: 近畿地方から東海地方にかけて広まっていた、銅鐸による祭祀を行っていた銅鐸文明を、「魏志倭人伝」に記載された道具であり、『日本書紀』にも著される矛（剣）、鏡、勾玉の、いわゆる三種の神器を祭祀に用いる「銅矛文明」が滅ぼしたとされる説。
sen.e: There is a theory that the bronze spearhead civilization, which used the so-called Three Imperial Regalia in its rituals - a sword, a mirror and a curved jewel, described in 'Gishiwajinden' and also in "Chronicles of Japan"- destroyed the bronze bell civilization, whose solemn rituals used bronze bells and which had spread from Kinki region to Tokai region.
